ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Tinnitus secondary to concussion
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Sudden onset of tinnitus following a motor-vehicle accident with whiplash and head injury.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Sensorineural hearing loss (Traumatic)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Asymmetric high-frequency hearing loss (left worse than right) consistent with the side of impact and trauma history.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Hyperacusis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Significant sound sensitivity preventing suprathreshold reflex testing; reported discomfort with loud sounds.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Baseline assessment of hearing thresholds given reported tinnitus and trauma.
Assessment of retrocochlear pathology, though often limited by hyperacusis.
Cross-check of cochlear outer hair cell function, particularly for asymmetric loss.
Psychoacoustic characterization of tinnitus (pitch, loudness, masking levels).
Patient-driven pitch matching to address patient anxiety and desire for precision.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Results revealed asymmetric high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss (Left worse than Right) with normal middle ear function. Acoustic reflexes were aborted due to significant sound sensitivity (hyperacusis). Tinnitus was matched to a high frequency (~9 kHz) with severe functional impact (THI 68, TFI 76) and high anxiety. DPOAEs were reduced in the left ear, consistent with the hearing loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear normal through 6 kHz with mild-to-moderate loss at 8 kHz+; Left ear mild-to-moderate SNHL above 3 kHz.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Jerger Type A bilaterally, indicating normal middle ear function.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Aborted due to uncomfortable loudness (UCL) reached at 80-90 dB HL; not conducted.

tests.name: Distortion Product Otoacoustic Emissions (DPOAE)
tests.result_summary: Present at 6-dB SNR; normal amplitudes for 8/13 frequencies in Right ear vs 4/13 in Left ear.

tests.name: Tinnitus Assessment
tests.result_summary: Pitch match ~9000 Hz; Loudness match 12 dB SL; MML 58 dB SL (Left); Residual Inhibition 3 seconds.

tests.name: Self-Directed Tinnitus Match (Levo)
tests.result_summary: Patient localized tinnitus to 8,558 Hz; process took 15 minutes and provided reassurance.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: One-month follow-up. Patient began sound enrichment at home using the masker-app and classical music at a comfortable volume.
Three-month follow-up. Patient attended a first visit with CBT and decided not to pursue it, reporting good strategies for working through her anxiety.
Six-month follow-up. Patient reported symptoms improved dramatically and she was managing tinnitus well with TRT device/streamed masking sounds. Sleep improved; transitioned to Melatonin.

proposed_items: Mild amplification (hearing aid) for the left ear
Sound enrichment (masker-app, classical music, streamed masking sounds)
Sleep hygiene adjustments (transition from Desyrel to Melatonin)
Filtered earplugs (ETY plugs) for sporting events
counseling_actions: Counseling on the nature of tinnitus and the purpose of testing (approximation vs. exact performance)
Explanation of the benefits of amplification for tinnitus treatment and auditory enrichment
Reassurance regarding test results to alleviate performance anxiety
Instruction on progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) for anxiety and sleep

escalation.rationale_short: Referral for cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) to address severe anxiety and sleep disturbance, while neurology managed the head injury and ruled out retrocochlear pathology.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor tinnitus handicap scores (THI/TFI), adjust TRT/sound therapy, and assess habituation.

expected_outcome: 1-month follow-up: THI score 62 and TFI score 78.
3-month follow-up: THI score 48 and TFI score 50.
6-month follow-up: Concussion symptom checklist 33, THI 36, and TFI 48.
Patient reported symptoms improved dramatically and she was managing tinnitus well with TRT device/streamed masking sounds.
Sleep improved; patient transitioned to Melatonin and discontinued Desyrel.
